$44,000,000 only! and this immense increase attributable to her railroads—I say, attributable to her
railroads alone ! No commercial excitement, nor
extravagant speculative fever has happened to her,
more than to any other State in the Union, in
that time; nor has any local cause stimulated this
vast increase. It is not her manufactures, for as
man> factories have, perhaps, gone out of existence, or suspended, as there have been new ones to
supply their places within that period. The value
imparted to property, in the towns and counties
(for the same period) through which these roads
run, is $156,000,000 over what it was in 1840,
leaving $134,653,560 as the general indirect power
of railroads to impart value to property in the
State, contiguous to, but through which they do
not run. In Georgia, lands that in 1846 could be
readily bought for twenty-live and fifty cents per
acre, now, that her railroads have developed
them, command ten, twelve and fifteen dollars per
acre. In point of fertility, those lands bear no
comparison to the lands through which this road
is designed to run. From a map of this section of
our State, from Algiers to Opelousas, made by the
Surveyor General, designating all the swamp and
overflowed lands it contains, it appears there arc
over 11,000,000 of acres of land, of which only
373,000 acres arc marked as swamp or overflowed
lands, leaving more than 13,000,000 of acres of
cultivatable lands. If Georgia, by her railroads,
in four years, was enabled to impart an additional
value to her inferior soil of ten or twelve dollars
